best_practices: Use React.FC<Props> pattern with TypeScript for type safety
Wrap lazy-loaded components in SuspenseLoader to prevent layout shift
Use useSuspenseQuery for data fetching with proper cache-first strategy
anti_patterns: Never use early returns with loading spinners (causes layout shift)
Never use react-toastify for notifications (use useMuiSnackbar instead)
Never use makeStyles or styled() components (use sx prop instead)

faq.question: Which React libraries does this skill cover?
faq.answer: TanStack Query for data fetching, TanStack Router for routing, MUI v7 for UI components, React Hook Form with Zod for forms.

faq.question: What data fetching patterns are recommended?
faq.answer: useSuspenseQuery is the primary pattern. Use with SuspenseLoader and implement cache-first strategy checking grid cache before API calls.

faq.question: How should I organize my frontend files?
faq.answer: Use features/ directory for domain-specific code with api/, components/, hooks/, helpers/, types/ subdirectories. Use components/ for reusable UI.

faq.question: Is my data safe when using this skill?
faq.answer: Yes. This skill only provides documentation and guidelines. It does not access files, make network requests, or execute code on your system.

faq.question: Why avoid early returns for loading states?
faq.answer: Early returns cause layout shift (CLS), which hurts user experience and Core Web Vitals. Use SuspenseLoader instead to maintain consistent layout.

faq.question: How is this different from backend-dev-guidelines?
faq.answer: Frontend-dev-guidelines covers React/TypeScript client patterns while backend-dev-guidelines covers Node.js/Express server patterns including API routes, controllers, and database access.
